article.title: Magnetar-Powered Supernovae in Two Dimensions. II. Broad-Line Supernovae Ic

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the shaded gray area in Figure 1 represent?
choices: The mass coordinate of the silicon shell.
The mass of the carbon-oxygen core.
The mass of the iron core that collapses to form a proto-neutron star.
The mass of 56Ni synthesized during the explosion.

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 2, what do the yellow regions within the core represent?
choices: Regions where carbon burning is actively occurring.
Regions with the necessary conditions (temperature and density) for 56Ni synthesis.
Regions where the shock wave has already passed.
Regions where the magnetar\'s energy deposition is most efficient.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 3 illustrates the accretion history in Model A, a jet-driven explosion. What causes the oscillations observed in the accretion rate?
choices: Pulsations from the newly formed neutron star.
Interaction between the jet and the stellar envelope.
Sound waves generated by the accretion flow.
Radioactive decay of 56Ni near the accreting object.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 4 depicts the outflow driven by the jet in Model A. What is the red line marking in the right panel?
choices: The boundary between the jet material and the stellar material.
The boundary of the region where the jet deposits its energy.
The boundary of jet-heated gas.
The shock front propagating through the star.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which model in Figure 5 shows the least amount of mixing at the time of shock breakout?
choices: Model A (jet-driven explosion)
Model B (wind-driven explosion)
Model C (jet and wind with 2.5° half-opening angle)
Model D (jet and wind with 10° half-opening angle)

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the roughly evenly spaced velocity contours in Figure 6 indicate?
choices: The presence of strong magnetic fields in the ejecta.
Homologous expansion of the ejecta.
The formation of a reverse shock in the ejecta.
The interaction of the ejecta with the circumstellar medium.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 7 shows the distribution of elements in the ejecta. Which model most closely resembles the element distribution in a typical core-collapse supernova?
choices: Model A
Model B
Model C
Model D

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the cause of the initial sharp, luminous peak in the light curves shown in Figure 8?
choices: Radioactive decay of 56Ni
Shock breakout
Interaction of the ejecta with the CSM
Recombination of hydrogen in the ejecta

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 9, which model(s) show a clump of 56Ni breaking through the ejecta along the axis of the jet?
choices: Model A only
Model B only
Models A, C, and D
Models C and D only
